queries.company_overview:
What it does: Microsoft provides cloud infrastructure (Azure), enterprise productivity and AI (Microsoft 365/Copilot), developer tools (GitHub), and personal computing (Windows, devices, gaming, advertising).
Main business units / segments:
- Productivity and Business Processes
- Intelligent Cloud
- More Personal Computing
High-level financials: FY2025 (fiscal year ended 2025-06-30) revenue: $281.7B; net income: $101.8B. Market capitalization: $4.00T as of 2025-10-29.
Competitive positioning: Azure is one of the top global hyperscale clouds, competing primarily with Amazon AWS and Google Cloud. Microsoft 365 (with Teams) is a leading enterprise productivity platform competing with Google Workspace and Salesforce Slack. Windows, Xbox, and GitHub compete with Apple hardware/software, Sony/Nintendo in gaming, and GitLab/Atlassian in developer tools.
Recent major news:
- 2025-10-14 Microsoft announced in-country data processing for Microsoft 365 Copilot in the UAE.
- 2025-09-24 Microsoft expanded model choice in Microsoft 365 Copilot by adding Anthropic models.
- 2025-09-18 Microsoft detailed the Fairwater AI datacenter in Wisconsin and a $4B additional investment.
- 2025-09-12 European Commission accepted Microsoft’s commitments on Teams bundling and interoperability.
- 2025-07-30 Microsoft reported Q4 FY2025 results and FY2025 revenue of $281.7B, net income $101.8B.

What is Microsoft's disclosed Microsoft.query: What is Microsoft's disclosed Microsoft Cloud gross margin trend including AI infrastructure impacts?
What is Microsoft's disclosed Microsoft.answer: Microsoft discloses that Microsoft Cloud gross margin has been trending lower as it scales AI infrastructure: 72% in Q3 FY24, 70% in Q4 FY24, 71% in Q1 FY25, 70% in Q2 FY25, and 69% in Q3 FY25. Management explicitly attributes the year-over-year compression to the impact of scaling AI infrastructure, as noted in its FY25 Q2 and Q3 performance commentary.

search_results.title: FY25 Q3 - Investor Metrics
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Investor Metrics table shows Microsoft Cloud gross margin percentage at 72% (Q3 FY24), 70% (Q4 FY24), 71% (Q1 FY25), 70% (Q2 FY25), and 69% (Q3 FY25), illustrating a gradual decline alongside the company’s AI build-out.

search_results.title: FY25 Q3 - Performance - Investor Relations - Microsoft
search_results.snippet: Microsoft states its Microsoft Cloud gross margin percentage decreased to 69% in Q3 FY25, explicitly citing the impact of scaling its AI infrastructure as the driver of the decline.

search_results.title: FY25 Q2 - Performance - Investor Relations - Microsoft
search_results.snippet: In Q2 FY25, Microsoft reports Microsoft Cloud gross margin percentage decreased to 70%, driven by scaling its AI infrastructure, reinforcing the ongoing margin pressure from AI-related build-out.

What organizational changes has Microsof.query: What organizational changes has Microsoft's AI division announced under CEO Mustafa Suleyman in 2025?
What organizational changes has Microsof.answer: In 2025, Mustafa Suleyman’s Microsoft AI created the Advanced Planning Unit (APU), a team inside his office to study AI’s societal, health, and work impacts and to feed product recommendations across Copilot, Bing, and Edge. Microsoft also launched a new CoreAI – Platform and Tools division led by Jay Parikh to unify developer tools and AI platform teams and build the end‑to‑end Copilot/AI stack in close coordination with Microsoft AI. In parallel, Suleyman expanded Microsoft AI’s footprint with a new Zurich hub, hiring ex‑Google DeepMind researchers to accelerate audio, agentic, and vision capabilities.

search_results.title: Introducing CoreAI – Platform and Tools
search_results.snippet: Microsoft created a new CoreAI – Platform and Tools division to bring together Dev Div, AI Platform, and key Office of the CTO teams (AI Supercomputer, Agentic Runtimes, Engineering Thrive) to build the end‑to‑end Copilot/AI stack; led by EVP Jay Parikh, it will work closely with leaders including Mustafa Suleyman as Microsoft pushes 2025’s “model‑forward,” agentic applications.

search_results.title: Microsoft is forming a new unit to study AI’s impacts
search_results.snippet: Under Microsoft AI CEO Mustafa Suleyman, the company formed the Advanced Planning Unit (APU) inside his office to research AI’s societal, health, and work implications and produce product recommendations; the cross‑disciplinary team will operate across Silicon Valley and London and recruit economists, psychologists, and technical experts.

search_results.title: Microsoft’s AI boss just raided Google. He poached two scientists who built a tool that can transform ho-hum text into a riveting podcast
search_results.snippet: Suleyman expanded Microsoft AI by opening a Zurich hub and hiring ex‑Google DeepMind researchers (e.g., Zalán Borsos, Marco Tagliasacchi, Matthias Minderer) to advance audio, agentic, and vision capabilities for Copilot, calling Zurich an important hub alongside Microsoft AI’s growing London office.

What compliance steps is Microsoft takin.query: What compliance steps is Microsoft taking to implement EU Teams commitments by November 2025?
What compliance steps is Microsoft takin.answer: By November 1, 2025, Microsoft will implement the EU-accepted Teams commitments by rolling out global licensing and pricing changes: reintroducing suites with Teams alongside ‘no Teams’ options, enforcing minimum price deltas and standalone Teams minimums, and giving EEA customers switching rights and discount parity. Microsoft will also formalize interoperability and data portability by maintaining AppSource, enabling embedding of Office Web Apps, publishing a centralized developer resource, and providing APIs/tools to export Teams data. These legally binding obligations are monitored by a trustee, with core commitments lasting seven years (ten years for interoperability/data portability).

search_results.title: Evolving our productivity offerings to resolve European competition concerns about Teams
search_results.snippet: Microsoft details implementation steps and timing: effective November 1, 2025 it will reintroduce Enterprise suites with Teams while keeping ‘no Teams’ options and adjust global prices to meet minimum deltas (e.g., €8 for E3/E5; €3 for Business Standard/Premium/E1; €1.50 for Business Basic; Teams Enterprise minimum €8). EEA customers get five years of annual switching rights and equal percentage discounts on ‘no Teams’ suites. Microsoft will maintain AppSource, allow embedding Office Web Apps via MDCPP, launch a centralized developer resource, and provide APIs/tools to export Teams data.

search_results.title: Commission accepts commitments offered by Microsoft to address competition concerns related to Teams
search_results.snippet: EU makes Microsoft’s Teams commitments legally binding (12 Sept 2025): Microsoft must offer suites without Teams at a lower price, allow EEA customers to switch to ‘no Teams’ suites, ensure interoperability (APIs, embedding Office Web Apps, prominent integration), and enable data portability from Teams. After a market test, Microsoft agreed to increase price differentials, display ‘without Teams’ offers wherever ‘with Teams’ appears, and publish interoperability/data portability info; it will align worldwide offers and pricing. Obligations last seven years (ten for interoperability/data portability) and are overseen by a monitoring trustee with fast‑track arbitration.

search_results.title: Microsoft proposes commitments to resolve European competition concerns related to Teams
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s EU Policy post outlines the commitments: maintain availability of suites without Teams in the EEA for seven years with minimum price deltas and formalize interoperability (including access via add-ins and embedding Office Web Apps). If the EU accepts, Microsoft will align suite options and pricing globally and implement the commitments on the required timeline following the Commission’s decision.

What power constraints impact Microsoft'.query: What power constraints impact Microsoft's planned AI datacenters in North America and Europe?
What power constraints impact Microsoft'.answer: In North America, Microsoft’s AI datacenter build-out is being slowed by grid and transmission bottlenecks that create long interconnection timelines and “power delays,” leading the company to cancel or defer leases and consider on-site or private power solutions. In Europe, chronic grid constraints—most visibly Ireland’s de facto halt on new Dublin grid connections until 2028—and slow permitting limit power access, prompting Microsoft to shift expansion toward the Nordics and explore private-wire infrastructure.

search_results.title: Microsoft shifting data center focus away from Ireland due to lack of power availability - report
search_results.snippet: A Microsoft executive said chronic grid constraints in Ireland—including EirGrid’s de facto moratorium on new Dublin data center connections until at least 2028—are limiting power access and stifling development. As a result, Microsoft is diverting AI data center investment to the Nordics (with abundant hydro), and is considering private-wire or on-site power to work around slow European permitting.

search_results.title: Are power delays a strategic cover for Microsoft's recent data center pullback?
search_results.snippet: TD Cowen reports Microsoft canceled several hundred megawatts of U.S. data center leases, let more than a gigawatt of LOIs expire, and dropped land deals, with Microsoft citing “power delays.” The article highlights that access to reliable power has become the gating factor for AI campuses in North America, pushing hyperscalers toward colocated generation, microgrids, and even small modular reactors as utilities struggle to deliver large interconnections.

search_results.title: Microsoft's AI Datacenter Cancellations Raise Concerns Over Generative AI Growth
search_results.snippet: Analysts say Microsoft terminated a “couple of hundred MW” of leases across multiple U.S. markets due to power delay issues and paused additional site qualifications. While some argue oversupply could be a factor, Microsoft’s response about pacing infrastructure underscores that grid and interconnection delays are constraining near-term AI data center deployment in North America.

What near-term pricing changes has Micro.query: What near-term pricing changes has Microsoft announced for Microsoft 365 Copilot enterprise SKUs?
What near-term pricing changes has Micro.answer: Microsoft announced that, starting December 1, 2024, Microsoft 365 Copilot (including Copilot for Sales and Copilot for Service) will offer a monthly billing option for annual-term subscriptions, priced 5% higher than paying annually up front. It also said that beginning April 1, 2025, all monthly-billed annual subscriptions across channels will be standardized to carry a 5% premium versus annual billing, while the annual list price itself remains unchanged.

search_results.title: Flexible billing for Microsoft 365 Copilot, Pricing updates for annual subscriptions & Teams Phone
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Nov 12, 2024 post introduces a monthly billing option for annual-term Microsoft 365 Copilot (including Copilot for Sales and Service) starting Dec 1, 2024, priced 5% above annual upfront. It further standardizes pricing on Apr 1, 2025 so monthly-billed annual subscriptions (across Buy Online, CSP, MCA-E) carry a 5% premium; the annual billing price remains unchanged.

search_results.title: Pricing Updates for Microsoft 365 Copilot and Other Per User Products (Partner FAQ) [PDF]
search_results.snippet: This partner FAQ confirms that on Dec 1, 2024, monthly billing for annual subscriptions of Microsoft 365 Copilot, Copilot for Sales, and Copilot for Service launches across Buy Online, CSP, and MCA-E, at a 5% premium vs annual billing; annual prices do not change. It also details an Apr 1, 2025 standardization where all monthly-billed annual subscriptions are priced 5% higher than annual upfront across channels and segments.

search_results.title: Microsoft Price Increases and “Flexible” Copilot Billing Are Coming: How to Prepare
search_results.snippet: UpperEdge highlights Microsoft’s new monthly billing model for M365 Copilot starting Dec 1, 2024 with a 5% uplift over annual upfront (e.g., $31.50 vs $30 for Copilot), and notes broader pricing updates effective Apr 1, 2025 (e.g., Teams Phone, Power BI). The analysis explains how these changes affect enterprise negotiations and budgeting.

What is Microsoft's publicly stated road.query: What is Microsoft's publicly stated roadmap for in-house AI models across 2025-2026?
What is Microsoft's publicly stated road.answer: Microsoft’s public roadmap indicates a 2025 kickoff with its first in‑house models—MAI‑Voice‑1 (already in Copilot Daily/Podcasts and demoable in Copilot Labs) and MAI‑1‑preview (public testing on LMArena)—followed by rapid iteration, phased Copilot integration, and orchestration of multiple specialized models. Leadership describes a five‑year plan and says “next versions” are already in training on new GB200‑class clusters, emphasizing cost‑efficient training/inference. In parallel, Microsoft is advancing its in‑house Phi‑4 small‑model family (reasoning and multimodal variants) for efficient cloud and on‑device use, with 2025 releases optimized to run on Copilot+ PC NPUs—signaling continued SLM updates through 2026.

search_results.title: Two in-house models in support of our mission
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s in-house model roadmap starts with MAI‑Voice‑1 (now used in Copilot Daily/Podcasts and available as a Copilot Labs demo) and MAI‑1‑preview (public testing on LMArena) as first steps. The company says it will “spin the flywheel” to deliver improved models in the coming months and plans to orchestrate a range of specialized models for different user intents, with more updates to come.

search_results.title: Microsoft unveils powerful new homegrown AI models
search_results.snippet: Microsoft AI chief Mustafa Suleyman outlines a five‑year roadmap and says the team is already working on next versions on GB200-class clusters; 2025 launches include MAI‑Voice‑1 and MAI‑1‑preview, with phased Copilot integration. The strategy emphasizes efficiency—MAI‑1‑preview was trained on ~15,000 H100s—and continued iteration to bring in‑house models into Microsoft products.

search_results.title: One year of Phi: Small language models making big leaps in AI
search_results.snippet: Microsoft details its 2025 in‑house small‑model track with Phi‑4 reasoning variants and multimodal models, designed for efficient cloud and edge use. The post notes 2025 releases are NPU‑optimized for Copilot+ PCs (with a May 2025 update enabling on‑device execution), signaling ongoing Phi family iterations and on‑device deployments that extend into 2026.

Which suppliers will provide Microsoft H.query: Which suppliers will provide Microsoft HBM3E memory for 2025-2026 AI deployments?
Which suppliers will provide Microsoft H.answer: Evidence indicates Microsoft will rely primarily on SK hynix and Samsung for HBM in 2025–2026. SK hynix has secured Microsoft as a key client for customized HBM (with HBM3E the mainstream in 2025), and Samsung is developing custom HBM for Microsoft (HBM4 timing into 2026). With HBM3E supply largely booked through 2025 at SK hynix and Micron as hyperscalers like Microsoft ramp AI, these are the key suppliers behind Microsoft’s 2025–2026 deployments.

search_results.title: SK Hynix leads Samsung in customized HBM; lands Nvidia, Microsoft deals
search_results.snippet: KED Global reports SK hynix has secured Microsoft as a key client for customized HBM, with its first custom part (likely HBM4E) targeted for H2 2026; it also notes HBM3E as the mainstream in 2025—pointing to SK hynix as a Microsoft HBM supplier across the 2025–2026 window.

search_results.title: Samsung to develop custom chips for Microsoft, Meta
search_results.snippet: Maeil’s Pulse says Samsung is developing customized HBM for Microsoft’s Maia AI chip, aiming to complete HBM4 development by end‑2025 with mass production to follow—signaling Samsung as a Microsoft HBM supplier into 2025–2026.

search_results.title: HBM supply from SK hynix and Micron sold out until late 2025
search_results.snippet: Tom’s Hardware notes SK hynix and Micron HBM3E supplies are largely booked through 2025 as hyperscalers like Microsoft ramp AI processors—underscoring who supplies HBM3E that Microsoft’s 2025 deployments will draw from.

What recent enterprise wins has Microsof.query: What recent enterprise wins has Microsoft Azure disclosed from AWS or Google Cloud?
What recent enterprise wins has Microsof.answer: A flagship recent takeaway is Coca‑Cola’s $1.1B, five‑year deal making Microsoft its preferred cloud and migrating all applications to Azure; Coca‑Cola previously used AWS and Google Cloud. Microsoft also launched a VMware Rapid Migration plan explicitly targeting VMware Cloud on AWS customers to move those workloads to Azure VMware Solution. In earnings commentary, Microsoft has said customers running on other clouds are now choosing Azure for new AI workloads—an implied stream of competitive wins from AWS and Google Cloud.

search_results.title: Microsoft wins $1.1bn cloud and AI contract from Coca-Cola
search_results.snippet: Coca‑Cola committed $1.1B over five years to make Microsoft its preferred cloud and AI provider and will migrate all its applications to Azure. The report notes Coca‑Cola had previously been a customer of both AWS and Google Cloud, highlighting this as a competitive win for Azure.

search_results.title: Introducing the VMware Rapid Migration Plan
search_results.snippet: Microsoft unveiled a migration program that directly courts VMware Cloud on AWS customers, offering HCX‑based cloud‑to‑cloud moves into Azure VMware Solution plus incentives/discounts. It positions Azure to capture VMware workloads transitioning off AWS or other clouds.

search_results.title: Is Microsoft Snatching AWS Customers? Nadella Drops Big Hint
search_results.snippet: In earnings remarks summarized here, Satya Nadella said customers using other clouds are now using Azure for new AI workloads—signaling competitive takeaways from rivals. While not naming AWS or Google Cloud, the context makes clear Azure is winning workloads from other hyperscalers.

What is Microsoft's latest disclosed Cop.query: What is Microsoft's latest disclosed Copilot engagement and retention metrics across enterprise tenants?
What is Microsoft's latest disclosed Cop.answer: Microsoft now exposes Copilot engagement and retention via the Copilot Dashboard, including Usage intensity (frequency of Copilot actions) and Returning users (weekly or monthly retention, defined as users active in both the current and prior period). In October 2025, Microsoft began rolling out Benchmarks that compare percentage of active Copilot users and returning user percentage across companies, using anonymized, aggregated tenant data. Separately, Microsoft reported that daily enterprise users more than doubled quarter over quarter and that Copilot habits typically stick after about 11 weeks when users save at least 11 minutes per day.

search_results.title: Benchmarks to compare Copilot adoption coming to Copilot Dashboard
search_results.snippet: Microsoft is adding Benchmarks to the Copilot Dashboard so organizations can compare adoption internally and externally. It surfaces percentage of active Copilot users and returning user percentage, and enables cross‑company comparisons (Top 10%/Top 25%) using anonymized, aggregated data across enterprise tenants.

search_results.title: Connect to the Microsoft Copilot Dashboard for Microsoft 365 customers
search_results.snippet: The Copilot Dashboard provides engagement and retention metrics: Usage intensity shows how frequently employees take Copilot actions; Consistent usage groups weeks with at least one action; Returning users tracks weekly or monthly retention (users active in both the current and preceding period). It also reports Copilot assisted hours to quantify value.

search_results.title: Microsoft's AI software is gaining traction with enterprise customers
search_results.snippet: Jared Spataro said Copilot daily users more than doubled quarter over quarter, and a six‑month study of 60 companies found habits stick after ~11 weeks when users save at least 11 minutes per day—practical signals of enterprise engagement depth and retention.

search_results.title: Microsoft’s AI business has topped an annual revenue run rate of $13 billion
search_results.snippet: Fortune reports that Satya Nadella said Microsoft’s AI business has reached a $13B annualized revenue run-rate, alongside 31% Azure growth; no distinct Azure OpenAI Service run-rate figure is provided.

search_results.snippet: GeekWire notes Microsoft is generating $13B annually from AI products and services; Azure grew 31% with 13 percentage points from AI, and bookings rose partly due to a new Azure commitment from OpenAI—yet no standalone Azure OpenAI Service run-rate is disclosed.

Which utilities have signed new power pu.query: Which utilities have signed new power purchase agreements supporting Microsoft AI datacenter capacity additions?
Which utilities have signed new power pu.answer: Recent PPAs tied to Microsoft’s expanding cloud/AI datacenter load include: Constellation Energy’s 20-year deal to restart the 835 MW Three Mile Island Unit 1 in PJM; RWE’s two 15-year PPAs for 446 MW of new onshore wind in Texas; and SSE Renewables/FuturEnergy Ireland’s long-term CPPA for the 30 MW Lenalea Wind Farm to power Microsoft’s Irish data centers. Together, these agreements add reliable, carbon-free capacity to grids serving Microsoft’s growing AI infrastructure.

search_results.title: Constellation plans 2028 restart of Three Mile Island unit 1, spurred by Microsoft PPA
search_results.snippet: Constellation Energy signed a 20-year PPA with Microsoft to restart the 835‑MW Three Mile Island Unit 1 in Pennsylvania, with the output used to match power consumed by Microsoft’s PJM data centers. The company plans a 2028 restart and a ~$1.6 billion investment—adding firm, carbon‑free capacity to support surging AI/datacenter demand.

search_results.title: RWE signs two 15-year Power Purchase Agreements with Microsoft
search_results.snippet: RWE agreed two 15‑year PPAs with Microsoft for clean electricity from two new onshore wind farms in Texas (Peyton Creek II and Lane City) totaling 446 MW. The projects expand RWE’s Texas footprint and provide additional renewable supply to meet Microsoft’s growing electricity needs as it scales cloud and AI data center capacity.

search_results.title: Power purchase deal inked with Microsoft for Lenalea wind farm
search_results.snippet: SSE Renewables and FuturEnergy Ireland announced a long‑term Corporate PPA with Microsoft for the 30 MW Lenalea Wind Farm in County Donegal. The renewable output will help power Microsoft’s data centre operations in Ireland and adds new clean capacity to the grid amid the company’s broader AI-driven expansion.

What is Microsoft's current AI datacente.query: What is Microsoft's current AI datacenter GPU inventory and weekly deployment throughput?
What is Microsoft's current AI datacente.answer: Microsoft doesn’t disclose an exact GPU count, but credible estimates and supplier disclosures suggest it currently operates on the order of 0.75–0.9 million H100‑equivalent GPUs as of end‑2024, with 2025 totals likely higher after purchasing 485,000 Nvidia Hopper GPUs in 2024 and beginning large Blackwell deployments. On Nvidia’s May 2025 earnings call, management said major hyperscalers are each deploying nearly 1,000 NVL72 racks—about 72,000 Blackwell GPUs—per week on average; they noted Microsoft has already deployed tens of thousands of Blackwell GPUs and is ramping toward hundreds of thousands.

search_results.title: NVIDIA Q1 2026 Earnings Call
search_results.snippet: On Nvidia’s Q1 FY26 call (May 2025), CFO Colette Kress said that on average major hyperscalers are each deploying nearly 1,000 NVL72 racks per week—about 72,000 Blackwell GPUs—and added that Microsoft has already deployed tens of thousands of Blackwell GPUs and is expected to ramp to hundreds of thousands.

What near-term changes has Microsoft ann.query: What near-term changes has Microsoft announced to Windows and Office commercial licensing structures?
What near-term changes has Microsoft ann.answer: Microsoft has unbundled Microsoft Teams from Microsoft 365 and Office 365 commercial suites outside the EEA, effective April 1, 2024, introducing new “no Teams” suites and a standalone Teams Enterprise SKU for net‑new enterprise customers. For Windows, Microsoft launched a paid Windows 10 Extended Security Updates (ESU) subscription starting late 2025 that provides up to three years of security updates (with Year One priced at $61/device for organizations, and ESU included at no extra cost in certain Azure/Windows 365 scenarios). In addition, Microsoft updated outsourcing/hosting terms (Oct 2022) to broaden BYOL rights for Microsoft 365 Apps and Windows Server, added per‑virtual‑core Windows Server licensing, and eased Windows 10/11 virtualization—simplifying how customers deploy Windows and Office in partner clouds.

search_results.title: Realigning global licensing for Microsoft 365
search_results.snippet: Effective April 1, 2024, Microsoft is offering new commercial Microsoft 365 and Office 365 suites without Teams outside the EEA/Switzerland, plus a new standalone Teams Enterprise SKU. Net‑new enterprise customers who want Teams must buy a ‘no Teams’ suite and add Teams Enterprise; existing customers can renew as-is or switch at renewal. Business and Frontline suites gain parallel ‘no Teams’ options, realigning the Office/Microsoft 365 licensing structure globally.

search_results.title: Extended Security Updates (ESU) program for Windows 10
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Windows 10 ESU program provides paid annual security updates for up to three years after end of support (Oct 14, 2025). Year One for organizations is $61 per device via volume licensing, with prices doubling annually; minimum purchase is one license and coverage is cumulative. ESU is included at no additional cost for Windows 10 instances in Windows 365 and various Azure services, reflecting near‑term Windows commercial licensing changes.

search_results.title: New options for partner hosted cloud | Microsoft Licensing Resources
search_results.snippet: As of Oct 1, 2022, Microsoft expanded outsourcing/hosting terms with a new Flexible Virtualization benefit, enabling customers with SA/subscriptions to bring their own licenses (including Microsoft 365 Apps) to partner clouds. It introduced Windows Server per‑virtual‑core licensing and removed the VDA add‑on requirement for certain Windows 10/11 virtualization scenarios, simplifying Windows and Office deployment under commercial licensing in partner environments.

What is Microsoft's disclosed plan to mi.query: What is Microsoft's disclosed plan to mitigate European Union AI Act compliance risks in 2025-2026?

It will support customers with documentation and tooling (e.g., Transparency Notes, Purview Compliance Manager, Azure AI Content Safety, Azure AI Studio, PyRIT), engage with the EU AI Office (AI Pact, Code of Practice), and continue through 2026 to align with staggered obligations by updating engineering processes, governance, and standards.

What is Microsoft's disclosed AI trainin.query: What is Microsoft's disclosed AI training dataset governance framework and red-teaming processes?

Its red‑teaming processes are disclosed as part of an iterative govern–map–measure–manage lifecycle: Microsoft conducts pre‑deployment reviews and AI red teaming at both model and application layers, measures mitigation effectiveness, applies defense‑in‑depth controls, and augments internal efforts with external red teaming for highly capable models; operational guidance and tooling (e.g., PyRIT, bug bar, failure taxonomy) are provided by the Microsoft AI Red Team.

What is the status of Microsoft's Copilo.query: What is the status of Microsoft's Copilot Studio monetization for custom agent usage?
What is the status of Microsoft's Copilo.answer: Microsoft has fully monetized Copilot Studio custom agent usage via metered billing: organizations pay either pay‑as‑you‑go or with prepaid capacity packs, and capacity enforcement is now active (agents are disabled after 125% overage until capacity is added or resets). Interactive usage by Microsoft 365 Copilot–licensed users in Microsoft 365 apps (Copilot Chat, Teams, SharePoint, etc.) is zero‑rated for many scenarios. Marketplace monetization is not supported for Copilot Studio–built custom agents; only agents built with the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit can be submitted to the Microsoft Commercial Marketplace (with transactable SaaS offers).

search_results.title: Publish agents for Microsoft 365 Copilot
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s official publishing guidance explains that custom agents built with Copilot Studio can be shared internally (sideload, org catalog) and published to Microsoft 365 Copilot/Teams, but they cannot be submitted to the Microsoft Commercial Marketplace. In contrast, agents built with the Microsoft 365 Agents Toolkit can be listed in the marketplace (Teams Store/AppSource) and linked to a SaaS offer—enabling monetization.

search_results.title: Microsoft Copilot Studio Licensing Guide – June 2025
search_results.snippet: The licensing guide details that custom agent usage is metered in ‘messages’ available via $200 packs of 25,000 or pay‑as‑you‑go at $0.01 per message. It also notes zero‑rated interactive usage for Microsoft 365 Copilot–licensed users in Microsoft 365 apps (Copilot Chat, Teams, SharePoint) and outlines message rates for classic/generative answers, Graph grounding, agent actions, and AI tools.

search_results.title: Copilot Studio – Upcoming usage enforcement and behavior changes for message packs
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s Message Center notice (MC1056311) states that starting April 30, 2025, Copilot Studio enforces prepaid capacity for custom agents: after a tenant reaches 125% of message pack capacity, agents stop responding to new interactions and reject further requests until capacity is increased or reset. Microsoft recommends enabling pay‑as‑you‑go to cover overages and ensure continuity.

What is Microsoft's disclosed plan to ad.query: What is Microsoft's disclosed plan to address data center water usage and drought risks?
What is Microsoft's disclosed plan to ad.answer: Microsoft plans to become water positive by 2030 and to redesign data centers to drastically cut or eliminate cooling water use. It is deploying closed‑loop, direct‑to‑chip cooling that uses zero evaporative water, expanding use of reclaimed/rainwater, lowering WUE through audits and operations changes, and investing in watershed replenishment focused on high‑stress basins. In drought‑prone regions, Microsoft funds local projects (e.g., Lake Mead conservation under Arizona’s Drought Contingency Plan) to bolster supplies and mitigate drought risks.

Pilots are planned in Phoenix, AZ and Mt. Pleasant, WI, with new sites coming online from 2027.

search_results.title: Microsoft’s Datacenter Community Pledge: To build and operate digital infrastructure that addresses societal challenges and creates benefits for communities
search_results.snippet: Microsoft commits to design and operate datacenters to be water positive before 2030—replenishing more water than they consume and minimizing dependence on local resources. The pledge highlights watershed restoration and includes work in drought‑prone Arizona to support Lake Mead and meet the state’s Drought Contingency Plan commitments.

search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s water‑positive strategy centers on reducing datacenter water‑use intensity and replenishing more water than it consumes globally by 2030, prioritizing roughly 40 highly stressed basins. Measures include shifting to air/adiabatic and efficient cooling, and funding local watershed projects to improve availability and drought resilience.

What is Microsoft's disclosed interest r.query: What is Microsoft's disclosed interest rate exposure and hedging strategy on outstanding debt?

The company hedges interest‑rate exposure on certain fixed‑rate notes using interest rate swaps designated as fair value hedges, effectively converting those tranches to floating. Swap gains/losses are recognized in other income (expense) with offsetting changes in the hedged items, and the filings list interest rate contracts among designated hedging instruments.

The filing presents interest rate contracts among hedging instruments, indicating swaps are used to manage rate exposure on fixed‑rate debt.

What is Microsoft's disclosed strategy t.answer: Microsoft’s stated strategy is to offer a model‑agnostic “Models as a Service” layer in Azure AI (Foundry/Studio): a model catalog with third‑party and open‑source models (e.g., Llama, Mistral, Cohere, Jais) exposed via serverless, pay‑as‑you‑go inference APIs and hosted fine‑tuning, with built‑in content safety. This removes GPU provisioning, unifies access through the Azure AI Model Inference API, and mirrors the model‑marketplace approach of AWS Bedrock and Google Vertex AI.

search_results.title: Announcing Llama 2 Inference APIs and Hosted Fine-Tuning through Models-as-a-Service in Azure AI
search_results.snippet: Microsoft introduced “Models as a Service” in Azure AI, starting with Meta’s Llama 2, to provide serverless, pay‑as‑you‑go inference APIs and hosted fine‑tuning, plus built‑in content safety. The plan invites other providers to list their LLMs in Azure AI Studio—removing GPU provisioning and creating a model marketplace comparable to Bedrock and Vertex.

search_results.title: Microsoft launches Azure Models as a Service
search_results.snippet: At Ignite 2023, Satya Nadella said Azure will launch “Models as a Service” to bring the best selection of open‑source models to Azure (e.g., Stable Diffusion, Llama2, Mistral, Cohere Command), with token‑billed inference and hosted fine‑tuning. The goal is to let developers avoid GPU provisioning and expand beyond OpenAI—positioning Azure directly against Bedrock and Vertex AI.

search_results.title: Deploy models as serverless API endpoints (Azure Machine Learning docs)
search_results.snippet: Microsoft’s documentation explains deploying models from the Azure AI model catalog as serverless API endpoints with pay‑as‑you‑go, token‑based billing. Models are consumed via a unified Azure AI Model Inference API without hosting them in your subscription—mirroring Bedrock/Vertex’s serverless foundation‑model access and simplifying production use.

What antitrust commitments has Microsoft.query: What antitrust commitments has Microsoft agreed regarding interoperability with Teams competitors through 2032?
What antitrust commitments has Microsoft.answer: Microsoft agreed to legally binding EU antitrust commitments to ensure Teams rivals can interoperate with Microsoft 365. It must provide APIs offering effectively equivalent access to Microsoft services (e.g., Exchange Online calendar/contacts and meetings, SharePoint Online/OneDrive files, presence, and activity feeds/notifications), and support embedding Office Web Apps, while also enabling customers to export Teams data to competing tools. The overall commitments run 7 years (through 2032), with the interoperability and data‑portability obligations specifically lasting 10 years from the 2025 decision (through 2035).

search_results.title: Commission accepts commitments offered by Microsoft to address competition concerns related to Teams (Press release)
search_results.snippet: The European Commission made Microsoft’s commitments legally binding: sell Office/Microsoft 365 without Teams at reduced prices, allow switching for long‑term customers, provide interoperability for key functionalities between Teams’ rivals and Microsoft products, and enable customers to move their Teams data to competing services. Most obligations last 7 years, while interoperability and data portability commitments last 10 years.

search_results.title: Microsoft’s Article 9 Commitments (full text of commitments filed with the European Commission)
search_results.snippet: The commitments require Microsoft to make available to Teams competitors APIs with effectively equivalent functionality and data access to what Teams gets from Microsoft services, including Exchange Online (contacts, calendar, meetings, email, tasks), SharePoint Online and OneDrive (file retrieval/storage), presence, and activity feeds/notifications. The ‘Relevant Period’ is 7 years, except interoperability and data portability duties in paragraphs 8–15, which run 10 years.

search_results.title: Evolving our productivity offerings to resolve European competition concerns about Teams
search_results.snippet: Microsoft says its commitments formalize Microsoft 365 interoperability: maintaining the add‑in model and AppSource, enabling competitors to embed Office Web Apps, and making APIs available that provide access to Entra ID, Exchange Online, SharePoint Online, and OneDrive data equivalent to what Teams uses. Microsoft also offers APIs/tools for customers to export Teams data to other collaboration solutions.

What leadership changes occurred in Micr.query: What leadership changes occurred in Microsoft's Security, Azure, or Windows organizations in 2025?
What leadership changes occurred in Micr.answer: In 2025, Microsoft made two notable leadership/organizational changes. In June, Microsoft moved its CISO, Igor Tsyganskiy, out of the Microsoft Security organization to report directly to Scott Guthrie, EVP of the Cloud + AI group that runs Azure—aligning cybersecurity leadership closer to core cloud and AI engineering. Then in late September, Microsoft reunited its Windows engineering under Pavan Davuluri (President, Windows & Devices), bringing Windows client and server teams—and leaders for Core OS, Security, Fundamentals, and Engineering Systems—under one organization to accelerate an AI-first, “Agentic OS” vision; some low-level components (kernel/virtualization/WSL) remain tied to Azure Core.

The memo frames the move as putting the CISO team closer to core engineering systems and AI platforms to deliver “secure by design/secure by default,” while continuing tight collaboration with Microsoft Security.

search_results.title: Meet Pavan Davuluri, the new Windows chief leading Microsoft's big AI-powered comeback
search_results.snippet: In September 2025, Microsoft reunited its Windows engineering teams under Pavan Davuluri, President of Windows & Devices—bringing Windows client and server under one leadership after years of split ownership. search_results.snippet: Microsoft announced a reorganization consolidating Windows engineering—merging client and server teams and having Core OS, Data Intelligence, Security, and Engineering Systems leaders report to Pavan Davuluri. What steps is Microsoft taking to mitiga.query: What steps is Microsoft taking to mitigate export control risks affecting Azure AI chip availability?
What steps is Microsoft taking to mitiga.answer: Microsoft is lobbying to revise the AI Diffusion Rule so it can reliably deploy advanced AI chips in allied markets: it supports keeping qualitative security controls that confine exports to certified, trusted data centers, but urges removal of quantitative caps. It is also pushing the Commerce Department and BIS to expand and use the Data Center Validated End‑User model to replace shipment‑by‑shipment licenses, while resourcing Commerce to speed approvals and tighten anti‑diversion enforcement. In RPTAC remarks, Microsoft further recommended aligning security requirements to ISO/NIST and adopting scalable, self‑attesting controls to reduce regulatory bottlenecks.

search_results.title: The Trump administration can avoid a strategic misstep in the AI race
search_results.snippet: Microsoft argues the AI Diffusion Rule caps exports of critical AI components to many Tier Two allies, undermining confidence in future access to U.S. chips. The company backs qualitative safeguards that restrict deployments to certified, trusted data centers and calls for more Commerce resources to expedite approvals and strengthen anti‑diversion enforcement—while urging elimination of quantitative caps that threaten global AI infrastructure build‑out.

search_results.title: Microsoft on AI Export Controls
search_results.snippet: At BIS’s RPTAC, Microsoft urged replacing shipment‑by‑shipment licensing with an expanded Data Center Validated End‑User (VEU) framework to enable trusted, repeat exports to certified secure facilities. It recommended aligning eligibility with ISO/NIST standards and favoring standardized, self‑attesting security models over perpetual audits to ease bottlenecks that have constrained global AI service delivery.

search_results.title: Microsoft urges Trump to loosen AI chip restrictions for UAE, Saudi Arabia, India and others
search_results.snippet: Reporting on Brad Smith’s blog, this article details Microsoft’s push to loosen Biden‑era AI chip export caps on allied countries, warning that limited U.S. chip supply would drive partners to Chinese providers. Microsoft supports national security safeguards but seeks policy changes to secure dependable chip availability for AI data centers in allied markets.

search_results.title: Evolving our productivity offerings to resolve European competition concerns about Teams

search_results.title: Microsoft makes commitments on Teams to allay EU antitrust concerns

report:
# Microsoft (MSFT) — Equity Research Update

## 1) Investment Recommendation Summary
- Stance: BULLISH
- Rating: BUY
- Next-market-day view: Positive bias. We expect MSFT to trade modestly better than the broader mega-cap tech cohort on the next session, supported by accelerating AI-driven Azure growth, strong backlog, resilient ads, and continued capital returns, partially offset by ongoing cloud margin pressure from AI capex ramp.

## 2) Executive Summary
Microsoft’s AI-led demand cycle remains robust and quantifiably visible in: (i) accelerating Azure growth contribution from AI (16 ppt in FY25 Q3) [1][11][12], (ii) a record $368B commercial RPO (+37% y/y) that de-risks future revenue conversion [7][8][9], and (iii) improving AI capacity utilization disclosures (targeting 80–90% at scale) that should support unit economics over time [37]. While Microsoft Cloud gross margin has compressed to 69% on the back of AI infrastructure build-out [4][5][6], management signaled a path to better balance as assets come online and mix normalizes [36]. Balance sheet flexibility (net cash ~ $51B) [19], a rising dividend, and ongoing buybacks provide downside protection and optionality for sustained AI investment and returns of capital [29][30][31][32].

Near term, we expect incremental buyers to support the shares given the strength of backlog, ads momentum (search/news ads ex-TAC +21% y/y in FY25 Q4) [21], and continued visibility into AI demand. Risks center on near-term margin drag from capex/leases, power constraints for datacenters, and modeling opacity (no Azure AI revenue share disclosure) [4][5][6][40][1][11]. On balance, risk-reward skews favorable.

## 3) Company Overview
Microsoft operates three segments: Productivity and Business Processes, Intelligent Cloud, and More Personal Computing. The franchise spans Azure, Microsoft 365/Copilot, GitHub, Windows/devices, gaming, and advertising. Microsoft competes with AWS and Google Cloud in hyperscale, Google Workspace and Slack in productivity/collaboration, Apple/Sony/Nintendo in consumer computing/gaming, and GitLab/Atlassian in developer tools. FY2025 revenue was $281.7B with net income of $101.8B (fiscal year ended 2025-06-30). Market capitalization is approximately $4.0T as of 2025-10-29.

## 4) Key Findings by Category

- Revenue and Growth
  - Azure and other cloud services revenue grew 33% in FY25 Q3, with 16 percentage points of that growth from AI services (up from 13 points in FY25 Q2; 12 points in FY25 Q1) [1][11][3]. Microsoft does not disclose the share of Azure revenue or workloads attributable to AI; it reports AI’s contribution in “growth points” instead [1][11][12].
  - Search and news advertising revenue ex-TAC grew 21% y/y in FY25 Q4, showing resilience in Microsoft Advertising/Bing [21].

- Demand/Bookings/Backlog
  - Commercial remaining performance obligation (RPO) stood at $368B in FY25 Q4, up ~37% y/y, signaling strong multi-year cloud/enterprise commitment and visibility [7][8][9].

- Margins and Unit Economics
  - Microsoft Cloud gross margin trend: 72% (Q3 FY24) → 70% (Q4 FY24) → 71% (Q1 FY25) → 70% (Q2 FY25) → 69% (Q3 FY25); the decline is explicitly tied to scaling AI infrastructure [5][4][6].
  - Management messaging indicates AI workloads depress margins during the build-out phase, but margins should improve as long-lived assets come online and capacity balances; the company aims to stay “in balance” by fiscal year-end while preserving operating margin discipline [36].
  - Microsoft has previously extended server/network useful lives (a depreciation lever that affects reported cloud margins), underlining the importance of accounting and asset-life assumptions to model cloud profitability [34][35].

- AI Revenue Disclosure
  - Microsoft disclosed an AI business annualized run-rate of ~$13B in Q2 FY25; it has not broken out a distinct run-rate for Azure OpenAI Service [10].
  - Microsoft does not disclose Azure AI revenue mix nor AI workload share; only “growth contribution points” are provided [1][11].

- Cash Flow and Capex
  - Q4 FY25 free cash flow was $25.6B; capex is split between long-lived datacenter assets and servers (CPUs/GPUs) tied to demand. FCF is variable due to the cadence of datacenter construction and finance-lease timing [16].
  - Finance leases tied to cloud infrastructure are material: ~$46.2B finance-lease liabilities at 6/30/25, and ~$92.7B of uncommenced leases (primarily datacenters), pointing to multi-year capacity coming online [17].
  - Third-party estimates suggest FY26 capex could be ~$120–$125B (up from ~FY25 levels), reflecting AI/datacenter build acceleration; these are not company guidance and should be treated as external projections [22][23][24].

- Balance Sheet and Capital Structure
  - Net cash position ~ $51.4B at 6/30/25 (cash and short-term investments ~$94.6B; total debt ~$43.2B) [19].
  - Debt maturities are manageable ($3.0B in FY26; $9.25B in FY27; modest thereafter), with no commercial paper outstanding at year-end; liquidity supports repayment or refinancing [18][33].
  - Effective tax rate (FY26) guided to 19–20%; drivers include changes in tax law and geographic mix of earnings [13][15][14].

- Capital Returns
  - Dividend increased to $0.91 per share quarterly, setting the FY26 run-rate [30].
  - Board authorized a new $60B repurchase program in Sept-2024; as of 6/30/25, ~$57.3B reportedly remained under the current authorization, with a recent cadence of ~$3–4B per quarter [31][29][32].

- AI Infrastructure, Utilization, and Supply Chain
  - Microsoft reports AI hardware utilization improvements, targeting 80–90% utilization at scale through orchestration and pooling innovations, which should enhance ROI on GPU clusters [37].
  - Third-party reporting suggests Microsoft purchased ~485,000 Nvidia H100/Hopper GPUs in 2024; Nvidia indicated hyperscalers are deploying at very high weekly rates and expects Microsoft to ramp to hundreds of thousands of Blackwell GPUs over time. These are external data points, not direct Microsoft disclosures [38][39].
  - Power availability is emerging as a gating factor for hyperscaler AI campuses in North America; reports cite cancellations/expiration of leases/LOIs tied to power delays—an industry-wide constraint that could affect deployment timing [40].

- Competitive Positioning and Market Share
  - Industry trackers (Synergy Research) estimate Azure at ~20% global cloud infrastructure market share versus AWS at ~30% and Google Cloud at ~13% as of Q2 2025 [27][28].

- Not Disclosed / Modeling Gaps
  - No disclosed Azure-only gross margin; Microsoft reports aggregate “Microsoft Cloud” margins [35].
  - No disclosed churn rate for Microsoft 365 enterprise/commercial subscriptions [5][7][20].
  - No disclosed percentage of Azure revenue from AI, nor backlog of signed GPU/silicon capacity by vendor [1][11][25].

## 5) Investment Thesis

- Bull Case
  - AI flywheel accelerating: AI contributed 16 ppt to Azure growth in FY25 Q3, up sequentially, indicating durable demand and attach across workloads [1][11].
  - Deep backlog supports multi-year growth visibility: $368B RPO (+37% y/y) reduces top-line volatility and underpins forward revenue conversion [7][8][9].
  - Path to margin recovery: Management expects better balance as AI capacity ramps and utilization climbs (80–90% target), supporting margin normalization beyond the build phase [36][37].
  - Balance sheet strength and capital returns: Net cash, manageable maturities, a higher dividend, and steady buybacks create a supportive shareholder return profile through the AI investment cycle [19][18][30][31][32].
  - Diversified growth vectors: Ads momentum (+21% ex-TAC y/y in FY25 Q4) and broad enterprise productivity portfolio mitigate single-product risk and smooth macro sensitivity [21].

- Bear Case
  - Margin pressure persists longer: Microsoft Cloud GM fell to 69% in Q3 FY25 as AI infra scales; an extended capex/lease cycle could defer margin expansion versus expectations [4][5][6][17].
  - Power and supply chain constraints: Grid interconnections and on-site generation hurdles could slow datacenter timelines, pushing out AI revenue ramps [40].
  - Disclosure opacity: Lack of Azure AI revenue share, Azure-only gross margins, and GPU capacity backlog details complicate modeling, increasing estimate dispersion and surprise risk [1][11][35][25].
  - External capex expectations are elevated: Third-party FY26 capex estimates (~$120–$125B) could weigh on free cash flow optics and investor sentiment if realized without commensurate monetization [22][23][24][16].

## 6) Key Risks
- Execution risk on AI infrastructure scale-up, including power availability, permitting, and supply chain for accelerators [40][39].
- Prolonged gross margin compression if capacity remains underutilized or if mix remains skewed to costlier AI workloads longer than expected [4][5][6].
- Regulatory and legal risks (antitrust, privacy, AI governance), potentially affecting product bundling or monetization.
- Macroeconomic slowdown impacting enterprise budgets and ad demand; FX volatility.
- Competitive intensity in cloud and AI platforms from AWS and Google Cloud; potential pricing pressure alongside rapid model commoditization [27][28].
- Financial modeling risk given limited disclosure granularity for AI revenue mix, Azure-only margins, and customer churn [1][11][35][5][7][20].

## 7) Conclusion and Outlook
- Recommendation: BUY (BULLISH stance). We view MSFT as a high-quality AI infrastructure and application platform with visible multi-year demand (RPO strength), a credible path to margin re-acceleration as assets and utilization scale, and robust capital returns supported by a fortress balance sheet [7][8][9][36][37][19][30][31][32].
- Next-market-day expectation: Positive skew. Given accelerating AI contribution to Azure growth [1][11], resilient ads [21], and strong backlog [7][8][9], we expect incremental buyers to support the shares. Potential overhangs include continued discourse on capex intensity and near-term cloud margin pressure [4][5][6][22][23][24].
- What to watch near term:
  - Any updates on FY26 capex trajectory versus third-party expectations [22][23][24].
  - Commentary on cloud gross margin trajectory and timing to “balance” [36].
  - Further AI product monetization signals (Copilot attach/pricing) and utilization metrics [36][37].
  - Bookings/RPO momentum as a leading indicator for Azure demand [7][8][9].

On balance, we see Microsoft’s AI demand signal, backlog scale, and operating discipline outweighing near-term margin volatility, supporting a BUY rating with a constructive near-term trading bias.
